title: Hampi
summary: Hampi, also known as the Group of Monuments at Hampi, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site in east-central Karnataka, India. Predating the Vijayanagara Empire, it's mentioned in Hindu scriptures and remains an active religious center with sites like the Virupaksha Temple. From 1336 to 1565, Hampi served as the prosperous and wealthy capital of the Vijayanagara Empire, estimated to be the world's second-largest city by 1500. Chronicles by Persian and European travelers detail its grandeur, numerous temples, farms, and markets. In 1565, Hampi was conquered, pillaged, and destroyed by a coalition of Muslim sultanates, leaving it in ruins. The site spans 4,100 hectares, preserving over 1,600 structures of the last great Hindu kingdom in South India.
key_points: Hampi is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in Vijayanagara district, Karnataka, India.
It was the prosperous capital of the Vijayanagara Empire from 1336 to 1565, once considered the world's second-largest city.
Hampi predates the Vijayanagara Empire and is mentioned in Hindu religious texts like the Ramayana.
The city was conquered, pillaged, and destroyed by Muslim armies in 1565, remaining in ruins since.
It continues to be an important religious center, featuring the active Virupaksha Temple and an Adi Shankara-linked monastery.
The site covers 4,100 hectares and contains over 1,600 surviving structures, including forts, temples, and water structures.
timeline: Predates the Vijayanagara Empire; mentioned in the Ramayana and Puranas as Pampa Devi Tirtha Kshetra.
1336-1565: Served as the capital of the Vijayanagara Empire.
c. 1500: Estimated to be the world's second-largest city, after Beijing, and possibly India's richest.
1565: Conquered, pillaged, and destroyed by a coalition of Muslim sultanates, leading to its abandonment and ruin.
Modern Era: Designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, recognized for its austere, grandiose ruins.
important_figures: European travellers, particularly Portuguese (described Hampi's grandeur and wealth)
Adi Shankara (associated with an active monastery at Hampi)
Muslim sultanates (defeated the Vijayanagara Empire and destroyed Hampi)
UNESCO (designated Hampi as a World Heritage Site)
applications: Religious pilgrimage and worship at active temples like the Virupaksha Temple.
Tourism, attracting visitors globally as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Historical and archaeological research into the Vijayanagara Empire and South Indian history.
Cultural preservation and education about ancient Indian kingdoms and architecture.
Economic activity for surrounding towns through tourism and related services.
current_status: Hampi is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, existing largely in ruins but spread over 4,100 hectares with over 1,600 surviving structures. It continues to function as an active religious center with sites like the Virupaksha Temple. It is a major archaeological and tourist destination in Karnataka, India.
future_prospects: Continued preservation and conservation efforts as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Potential for further archaeological excavations and discoveries within the extensive ruins.
Development of sustainable tourism infrastructure to manage visitors while protecting the site.
Ongoing research to uncover more about the Vijayanagara Empire's history and culture.
Increased global recognition and visitation, fostering cultural exchange.
